subject: Sleep
title: Dolphins Sleep Half a Brain at a Time
description: A 60-second lesson on Dolphins Sleep Half a Brain at a Time.

hook.text: Dolphins never fully fall asleep. One half of their brain rests while the other stays awake. Always.

buildup.text: This is called unihemispheric slow-wave sleep. One eye closes while the opposite brain hemisphere sleeps.

discovery.text: Dolphins must consciously breathe. Full sleep would mean drowning. Half-brain sleep keeps them alive.

twist.text: They alternate hemispheres throughout the night, so each half gets rest without ever losing consciousness.

climax.text: Dolphins can swim, breathe, and watch for predators while technically asleep. It's nature's multitasking masterpiece.

punchline.text: Dolphins solved the drowning problem by only half sleeping.

quiz.question: Why do dolphins sleep with one brain hemisphere at a time?
options: They must stay conscious to breathe and avoid drowning
